Already invested so much in this project?  

Thinks, “If I just keep trying, I can make this work.”  

Hates admitting to mistakes in it now?  

Thinks, “What else could I do with this time or money if I pulled the plug now?”  

Comfortable with cutting losses.  

Sunk-cost bias is common.  

It isn’t the only Nonessentialist trap to watch out for.  

Below are several other common traps.  

Here are tips for how to extricate yourself politely.  

Do it gracefully and with minimal cost.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Sunk-cost bias can lead to a reluctance to abandon failing projects, making it essential to recognize and avoid this and other commitment traps.
